conclusion: To determine the refractive index of the glass, analyze the geometry and refraction of the light beam through the semi-cylindrical glass brick.
The semi-cylindrical glass brick has a radius R, with light incident at point A and exiting at point B.
The distance between points A and B is given as (sqrt(2)R)/2.
The light travels from point A to point B through the glass, and the path length inside the glass can be found using the geometry of the semi-circle.
The straight-line distance between A and B is (sqrt(2)R)/2, representing the chord of the semi-circle.
The angle subtended by this chord at the center O can be found using the chord length formula, leading to theta = 2 sin^(-1)(sqrt(2)/4).
Snell's Law relates the angle of incidence and refraction with the refractive indices.
Since the light exits symmetrically, the angle of incidence and refraction are equal.
The path length inside the glass is the arc length corresponding to the angle theta, and the actual path length through the glass is the straight-line distance.
Using the relationship between the arc length and the straight-line distance, the refractive index n is calculated as (2 theta)/sqrt(2).
Substituting theta = 2 sin^(-1)(sqrt(2)/4), n is calculated as (4 sin^(-1)(sqrt(2)/4))/sqrt(2).
Using the approximation for small angles, sin^(-1)(sqrt(2)/4) ≈ sqrt(2)/4, leading to n ≈ 1.
A more precise calculation using the exact value of sin^(-1)(sqrt(2)/4) is needed for accuracy.
The refractive index of the glass is approximately sqrt(2) or about 1.414, considering the geometry and the given distances.
